text: if ever there was a time of years to do
something just a little bit more
complicated now is the time that's why I
like to make decorated cookies at the

any other time today I'm making a
gingerbread bell it's a delicious
gingerbread cookie and the last part
which is the decorating part it's the
part that the kids are really gonna want
to get involved in the first thing that
you want to do is make your cookie dough
that's why I'm measuring out three and a
half cups of all-purpose flour a
teaspoon of baking soda it's really
lumpy so I'm just gonna press some of it
against the side to get the lumps out
first and then scoop it out a tablespoon
of dry ginger the ground dry ginger not
the fresh stuff major flavoring here two
teaspoons of ground cinnamon and a half
a teaspoon of cloves is it a very
flavorful cookie and then 1/2 a teaspoon
of fine salt whisk that all together the
huge and then for your butter based
ingredients one stick of unsalted butter
room temp and three quarters of a cup of
dark brown sugar
make sure it's packed and then cream
those together you'll notice when you're
creaming dark brown sugar or light brown
sugar and butter that it doesn't get his
light and fluffy as it does when you're
using white sugar that's because it's a
much denser product when it's creamed
you add your egg one large egg beat that
in and to add a little bit more
intensity and darkness of flavor I'm
gonna add 2/3 of a cup of unsalted
molasses some depth of flavor more depth
of flavor than you're already gonna get
which is a lot from all those spices
beat that in just till it's nice and
combined and then you can add your dry
ingredients and you're done that's easy
a lot of ingredients but it's not hard
slowly start beating in your flour so it
doesn't fly and then just raise the
beaters till it's like a medium-high and
mix it until it all comes together oh my
gosh I wish you guys could smell this it
smells like the holidays it's ridiculous
how evocative that smell of gingerbread
is right once it's all done you'll see
that it's the kind of wet dough and you
want to wrap that in plastic and
refrigerate it before you roll it out or
and disaster separate it into two and
then wrap it in plastic and Pat it into
disks and then refrigerate it for at
least an hour and even up to overnight
oops
you caught me this dough's been
refrigerating for one hour at least
remember when I said it was gonna be
kind of sticky cover your bases and roll
it between parchment otherwise it could
be kind of a nightmare
that's pretty generously on one sheet of
parchment unwrap your dough place it on
there and then dust the top with flour
again pop it with your second piece of
parchment and just start rolling I like
to move my dough around so that it's
nice and even as I'm rolling every once
in a while what I like to do to make
sure there's no sticking is grab both
pieces of parchment paper and then lift
it up and flip it over then you take the
top piece and then lift it off dust with
a little bit more flour and continue
rolling until you get to the thickness
that you're looking for for these
cookies I want it to be just over an
eighth of an inch thick once you have
the thickness you like then you're gonna
want to refrigerate it again for about
thirty minutes or you can freeze it for
ten minutes
here I have my chilled already dough
remove the parchment I have a three and
a half inch bell shaped cutter obviously
you can use whatever shape you want
place it on your chilled dough and cut
out your shapes arrange the cutter on
the dough as close together as possible
so you waste as little as possible it's
kind of like a puzzle right seal away
the unused portion and discard that and
then you have your cookies already on
your parchment lined sheet you'll
probably want to spread them out a
little bit because they're a little bit
close together right now and you want
them more evenly distributed for even
cooking one of these small offset
spatula is actually a really great tool
to run underneath your cookies to
release them from the parchment if
they're a little bit stuck I'm gonna
transfer these to a clean piece of
parchment now that they're all on a nice
clean baking sheet I can see that the
edges are a little bit like rough and
one of my tricks that I like to do is I
take a toothpick and I just run it along
the edge carefully removing any little
pieces of dough so that it's a nice
clean shape now you guys all think I'm
going insane this is one of those things
that just brings out the perfectionist
in me now that the edges are completely
clean you can put them into a 350 degree
oven to bake they need to be set you
don't want them turning to much darker
that'll take about 14 minutes when the
cookies are baked and cooled the fun
part comes the decorating so this one
we're going to decorate with royal icing
I have six cups of confectioner's sugar
in this bowl and to that I'm adding 1/2
a cup of pasteurized egg whites or any
egg whites I guess if you're not worried
about that kind of thing
3/4 of a teaspoon of cream of tartar and
then beating it all up together
starting on low once it's all combined
you can speed it up a little bit and
then just mix it until it's nice and
smooth and it needs to be a consistency
that is spreadable but isn't so thick
that it looks so if you feel like it's
not like that you can add a tiny bit of
water move I like to check it by lifting
some up and letting it fall back into
the big bowl and if it holds its shape
and just slowly goes into the rest of
the frosting it takes five seconds to
disappear I feel like that's the right
thickness I want to do two different
colors on my cookies so I want some
white and some pink take a ziploc bag
and place it into a glass just fold the
edges over the top that holds it in
place and then transfer about a half of
it still white into the back just twist
up the top of the ziplock bag and then
keep it closed with rubber band just so
none of the icing seeps out set it aside
for a second I'll show you what we're
gonna do with that later add the pink
food coloring to the rest of your icing
mixture start with a little and then
work your way up and put my pink icing
into the second bag you need to cut a
teeny teeny hole in the very very tip
because that's where the icing is gonna
come out but you don't want it too big
otherwise the ice is gonna fly all over
the place so cut off the very very tip
now that you have your colors prepared
it's time for that actual fun part which
is the decorating so take your base
color whichever you want pink or white
and you can alternate and then outline
on your bell the shape of your bell
leaving a little bit of an edge like a
quarter of an inch or less and I know
the kids are gonna want to do this part
and they're not gonna be precise and
that's okay just let them have a good
time I'm just telling myself so then
fill in in a nice even layer I just like
to move the tip of my bag back and forth
drawing the icing across the entire
cookie while it's still wet you'll do
your embellishment take your secondary
color cut a very small hole in the tip
of that bag too in this case it's my
white color and draw lines across if you
want them to be exactly like ours you
can do five which is what we did and
then you take a toothpick and draw it up
and down through the wet layers of icing
to make the fun little effect we did
three so I'm gonna do three to show you
it's actually really easy and once you

otherwise they'll get very messy but

all you have to do is before you bake it
